page.title: 01GENERAL IMPRESSION OF AREA
page.content: This is a rural, low-lying area with the most of the land about 30m.above sea level but with one part rising to 75m. Much of the area is water meadow, known as moorland, which is mud-rock and very damp. The area is largely grassland used for grazing cattle. Drainage is necessary and the fields contain a network of drainage ditches, locally called Rhynes. These are linked to the River Brue which flows through the area. The three centres of population, Butleigh, Barton St.David and Baltonsborough are situated on slightly higher ground. There are also two hamlets and eighteen farms. Buildings date back to the fourteenth century but much development has taken place since 1950. As there is little opportunity for employment in the area most of the inhabitants work elsewhere.
